author: potuz
content:
<@427491045308235776> seems that GLS254 doesn't  have an implementation in Golang? At least I didn't see bindings from the assembly/C/Rust implementations. 

Incidentally, what is the implementation of Ristretto that I should be using? I see there's https://github.com/gtank/ristretto255  and there's https://github.com/bwesterb/go-ristretto where you yourself added code. This latter library does not have an explicit MSM implementation it seems and you need to loop, while the previous library relies on https://github.com/FiloSottile/edwards25519 which does have a variable time MSM it seems.

author: potuz
content: It's driving me crazy that it seems that every single cryptographer that wanted to work with this curve reinvented the wheel instead of reuing code... which one should I be using?

author: potuz
content: A quick look and it seems that ristretto255 is the right option

author: kevaundray
content:
- Yep the GLS254 doesn't have a golang impl

- They both look interopable, I would use the gtank one if it has MSM -- I imagine that if we use Ristretto255, we would probably just re-implement the Ristretto part on top of stdlib and optimize the MSM algorithm

author: potuz
content: there's no Ristretto on the std lib afaik

author: kevaundray
content: Can you clarify, right now are the ristretto elements mostly zero bits?

author: kevaundray
content: Ristretto is built ontop of edwards25519, which should be in the stdlib -- though yep the Ristretto part is not in the stdlib

author: potuz
content: you can start with very small Ristretto scalars, but 1) they get multiplied in each hop and 2) you need to invert them

author: potuz
content: exactly, but the Ristretto255 library does not use the stdlib it uses the upstream fork which is more complete and is is against a previous version also

author: potuz
content: not having a Golang impl is a killer for me, I' ll stick to Ristretto for the time being

author: kevaundray
content: Yeah that should be updated I think

author: kevaundray
content:
I spoke too soon ðŸ™‚ 

The version in the golang stdlib is private, so they don't expose the necessary API, see `crypto/internal/fips140/edwards25519` 

So for updates, you would need to submit it to the golang stdlib, and then wait for the upstream fork to point to a newer version of the golang stdlib with that update
